questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Upon further investigation, a micturating cystourethrogram is performed and which is shown below. The boy is currently asymptomatic and has no history of renal or bladder abnormalities. What could be the cause of the symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vesicoureteral reflux

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is a common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. The condition is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and potentially up to the kidneys. Imaging findings showing dilated ureters on a micturating cystourethrogram are indicative of VUR.

questions.text: What is the sequence of performing a Thomas test?(INICET NOV 2021) Passive flexion of affected hip Overcorrection on the normal side Measure the flexion angle Checking for lumbar lordosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IV, II, I, III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of performing the Thomas test is:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of performing the Thomas test is:
  • ➤ Checking for lumbar lordosis
  • ➤ ↓
  • ➤ Overcorrection on the normal side
  • ➤ ↓
  • ➤ Passive flexion of affected hip
  • ➤ ↓
  • ➤ Measure the flexion angle

questions.explanation:

questions.text: Mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is:(NEET PG 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibits release of acetylcholine from lower motor neurons

questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibits release of acetylcholine from lower motor neurons
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inhibits release of acetylcholine from lower motor neurons

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin, produced by the bacterium Clostridium botulinum, exerts its mechanism of action by preventing the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. The toxin cleaves specific proteins involved in vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release, leading to the inhibition of acetylcholine release from lower motor neurons. This blockade of acetylcholine release results in muscle paralysis, making botulinum toxin useful for medical and cosmetic purposes to treat conditions characterized by excessive muscle activity.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 587

questions.text: What is the recommended amount of vitamin A dosage for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours

options.label: B
options.text: 1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week

options.label: C
options.text: 1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week

options.label: D
options.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.correct_answer: D. 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The suggested vitamin A dose for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia is 200,000 IU, administered promptly, then repeated with the same age-appropriate amount after 24 hours and again after a span of 2 weeks.
  • ➤ Dosage of Vitamin A as per age: -
  • ➤ <6 months – 50,000 IU orally 6-12 months – 1,00,000 IU orally above 12 months – 2,00,000 IU orally
  • ➤ <6 months – 50,000 IU orally
  • ➤ 6-12 months – 1,00,000 IU orally
  • ➤ above 12 months – 2,00,000 IU orally

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Supracardinal vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The supracardinal veins develop in the embryo as paired structures and are involved in the drainage of the body wall. On the right side, the supracardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while on the left side, it contributes to the formation of the hemiazygos and accessory hemiazygos veins.

questions.text: A female patient with celiac disease is recommended a gluten-free diet. Which among the following can she consume?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rice

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Celiac disease requires a strict gluten-free diet to avoid triggering symptoms. Gluten is found in certain grains, specifically:
  • • Mnemonic - BROW
  • • Mnemonic - BROW
  • • Barley Rye Oats (unless specifically labeled gluten-free due to potential cross-contamination) Wheat
  • • Barley
  • • Barley
  • • Rye
  • • Rye
  • • Oats (unless specifically labeled gluten-free due to potential cross-contamination)
  • • Oats
  • • Wheat
  • • Wheat
  • • Rice is naturally gluten-free and safe for consumption by individuals with celiac disease.
  • • Rice
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Wheat: Contains gluten and must be avoided.
  • • Option A. Wheat:
  • • Option B. Barley: Contains gluten and must be avoided.
  • • Option B. Barley:
  • • Option C. Oats: Often contaminated with gluten unless specifically labeled gluten-free and should be avoided unless confirmed to be safe.
  • • Option C. Oats:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Individuals with celiac disease should avoid wheat, barley, rye, and oats unless specifically labelled gluten-free, while rice is a safe option.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thiazides in DCT? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blockade of Na-Cl Symporter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiazide diuretics primarily work by inhibiting the sodium-chloride symporter in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney. This inhibition reduces sodium reabsorption, leading to increased excretion of sodium and water, thereby lowering blood pressure and reducing edema.

questions.text: 2,3-BPG causes the unloading of oxygen to tissues by? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Binding to beta subunit of Hb

questions.correct_answer: B. Binding to beta subunit of Hb
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Binding to beta subunit of Hb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) binds to the beta subunits of hemoglobin, decreasing its affinity for oxygen and promoting oxygen release to the tissues. This mechanism is crucial for adapting to conditions requiring increased oxygen delivery, such as high altitude and exercise.

questions.text: A suspect of sexual assault of 18 years of age claims to be of 16 years. X-rays of which area can confirm the correct age of the suspect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)  Knee and wrist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ossification of the wrist and knee is a reliable indicator of whether an individual is 18 years old, as both these areas ossify by that age.

questions.text: Which type of PCR is suitable for identifying multiple causative agents? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Multiplex PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiplex PCR is the best choice for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, making it efficient and comprehensive for diagnosing conditions caused by various pathogens.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is undergoing chronic medication therapy for a long-term condition. The healthcare team wants to maintain a specific steady-state plasma concentration of the drug. What formula should be used to calculate the maintenance dose rate of the drug for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clearance x Plasma concentration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula for calculating the maintenance dose rate (MD) of a drug is:
  • ➤ Maintenance Dose Rate (MD) = Clearance (CL) × Desired Plasma Concentration (Cp)
  • ➤ ×
  • ➤ This formula is used to achieve and maintain a specific steady-state plasma concentration of the drug

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus since the past 25 years, came for a health checkup. He was found to have uncontrolled blood sugar levels and third cranial nerve palsy. Which is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in such a case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Ptosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in diabetic patients, due to the selective ischemic damage to the central fibers of the oculomotor nerve, sparing the peripheral pupillary fibers.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gilbert syndrome is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia , resulting from reduced enzyme activity that impairs the conversion of unconjugated bilirubin to its conjugated form
  • ➤ Gilbert syndrome is a cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

questions.text: Ga-68 PSMA scan is useful for the diagnosis of which condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prostate cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ga-68 PSMA scan is specifically designed for the diagnosis and management of prostate cancer, as it targets the Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen expressed on prostate cancer cells.

questions.text: All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

options.label: B
options.text: Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia

options.label: C
options.text: Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia

options.label: D
options.text: Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF

questions.correct_answer: A. Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prostaglandins play an important role. Thromboxane A2 decreases; Prostacyclin: Thromboxane ratio increases in preeclampsia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except option A. There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI,) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA,) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia.
  • • All of the following are theories of causation of preeclampsia except option A. There is reduced or absent prostacyclin (PGI,) production with increased production of thromboxane (TXA,) and reduced ratio of prostacyclin: thromboxane in preeclampsia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia: Endothelial cell dysfunction is another etiology. Injured or activated endothelial cells may produce less nitric oxide and may secrete substances that promote coagulation and vasopressor sensitivity.
  • • Option B. Endothelial cell dysfunction leads to reduced nitric oxide levels and this causes the clinical presentation of preeclampsia:
  • • Option C. Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia: Vasospasm has long been associated with preeclampsia. Systemic endothelial activation causes vasospasm, which elevates resistance to produce hypertension. With diminished blood flow because of maldistribution from vasospasm and interstitial leakage, ischemia of the surrounding tissues can cause necrosis, hemorrhage, and other end-organ disturbances.
  • • Option C. Vasoconstriction leads to ischemia, necrosis and hemorrhage and end organ damage seen in preeclampsia:
  • • Option D. Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF:
  • • Option D. Anti-angiogenic factors play an important role in preeclampsia. There is an increase in FIt-1 and decrease in PIGF:
  • • Angiogenic Factors:
  • • Placental vasculogenesis is evident 21 days after conception. Two antiangiogenic peptides that are increased Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1) Soluble endoglin (s-eng) Factors that are decreased are PlGF PAPP-A VEGF
  • • Placental vasculogenesis is evident 21 days after conception. Two antiangiogenic peptides that are increased Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1) Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • • Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1) Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • • Soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (s-flt-1)
  • • Soluble endoglin (s-eng)
  • • Factors that are decreased are PlGF PAPP-A VEGF
  • • PlGF PAPP-A VEGF
  • • PlGF
  • • PAPP-A
  • • VEGF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In preeclampsia, the prostacyclin: thromboxane ratio is decreased due to increased thromboxane A2 and decreased prostacyclin (PGI2).
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1802, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1802, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023) 1.Pulmonary area 2.Erb’s area 3.Mitral area
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 → 2 → 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order from superior to inferior for heart sounds on the left side chest wall is pulmonary area, Erb’s area, and mitral area.

questions.text: A patient visits the clinic and presents with a raised and firm scar on their chest, which is larger than the original wound. The physician suspects a keloid scar and begins to explain the diagnosis and potential treatment options. Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: The extent does not cross the wound margins

options.label: B
options.text: Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence

options.label: C
options.text: Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity

options.label: D
options.text: A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.correct_answer: D. A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keloid scars are caused by an overproduction of growth factors like TGF-β, leading to excessive collagen formation and scar tissue that extends beyond the wound margins.

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis is due to which property of the codon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Degeneracy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code, allowing multiple codons to code for the same amino acid, with variation in the third (wobble) position of the codon.
  • ➤ Wobble bases
  • ➤ Wobble bases
  • ➤ 3rd base of the codon on mRNA and 1 st base of anticodon on tRNA in 5’ to 3’ direction are wobble positions.
  • ➤ Wobble hypothesis says that for binding between bases present in these positions, some imprecision is allowed. i.e. one base in anticodon can bind with various bases of codon. This is also called as degeneracy of codon i.e. There is more than one codon for one amino acid. So, Wobble hypothesis is due to degeneracy of codons.

questions.text: Cherry red color staining is due to: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Carbon monoxide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ (In Aniline Deep blue as well as Red Brown colour can occur)

  • ➤ Ref: Simpson’s Forensic Medicine, 13th edition, page 45
  • ➤ Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 83.
  • ➤ Text book of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 83.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs exacerbates myasthenia and is usually avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis? ( INICET Nov 2020) 1. Lidocaine 2. Aspirin 3. Meropenem 4. Phenytoin
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DRUGS THAT SHOULD BE AVOIDED IN MYSTHENIA GRAVIS
  • ➤ DRUGS THAT SHOULD BE AVOIDED IN MYSTHENIA GRAVIS

questions.text: All are long-term reversible methods of contraception, except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Female sterilization

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Long-Acting Reversible Contraceptives (LARC) are those which are administered at a frequency of less than once per month. LARC methods include:
  • • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years. Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years. Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.
  • • Intrauterine devices (IUDs): Such as CuT 380A with a lifespan of 10 years, and the Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD (LNG IUD) with a lifespan of 5 years.
  • • Intrauterine devices (IUDs):
  • • Implants: Implanon, which contains etonorgestrel, has a lifespan of 3 years, and Norplant II, which contains LNG, also has a lifespan of 3 years.
  • • Implants:
  • • Injectable contraceptives: Including Depo-Provera (DMPA) which is administered as 150 mg every 3 months, and Norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN) which is administered as 200 mg every 2 months.
  • • Injectable contraceptives:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Progestin injection: This is a form of LARC. Injectable contraceptives like DMPA and NET-EN are given at intervals of 2 to 3 months.
  • • Option A. Progestin injection:
  • • Option B. Progestin implants: These are also considered LARC. Implanon and Norplant II are examples of progestin implants with a duration of action up to 3 years.
  • • Option B. Progestin implants:
  • • Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices: Both types of IUDs are classified as LARC. The CuT 380A lasts for up to 10 years, and the LNG IUD lasts for up to 5 years.
  • • Option D. Levonorgestrel-releasing and copper-containing intrauterine devices:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARC) include intrauterine devices (IUDs), progestin implants, and injectable contraceptives, but do not include permanent methods like female sterilization.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition pg 491-492,479,
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 107,112, 127, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition pg 491-492,479,

questions.text: Which of the following triad is seen after an acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma? ( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vogt's triad

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vogt's triad in a patient with a history of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma can aid in rapid diagnosis and management of this potentially vision-threatening condition. It underscores the importance of timely intervention to preserve ocular health and prevent irreversible complications.

questions.text: In a patient, the hypothalamic thermostat was reset from point V to point X as shown below. Which of the following happens in stage W compared to stage Y? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Shivering

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the above scenario, the patient's hypothalamic thermostat has been reset to a higher temperature, hence the body uses methods like shivering to increase the temperature.
  • • Fig : Effects changing the set-point of the hypothalamic temperature
  • • Fig
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sweating
  • • Option B. Sweating
  • • Stage W : Sweating is unlikely in this phase because the body is in the process of heating up to meet the new higher set point. Sweating is a mechanism used to reduce body temperature and would be counterproductive at this stage. Stage Y : Sweating becomes prominent here as the body seeks to dissipate excess heat after reaching or surpassing the set point.
  • • Stage W : Sweating is unlikely in this phase because the body is in the process of heating up to meet the new higher set point. Sweating is a mechanism used to reduce body temperature and would be counterproductive at this stage.
  • • Stage W
  • • Stage Y : Sweating becomes prominent here as the body seeks to dissipate excess heat after reaching or surpassing the set point.
  • • Stage Y
  • • Option C. Increased blood flow to the skin
  • • Option C. Increased blood flow to the skin
  • • Stage W : There is typically decreased blood flow to the skin during this phase due to vasoconstriction, which helps to retain heat. Increasing blood flow to the skin would be counterproductive as it would lead to increased heat loss. Stage Y : Increased blood flow to the skin occurs in this phase to facilitate heat loss through the skin, aiding in thermoregulation by cooling the body down.
  • • Stage W : There is typically decreased blood flow to the skin during this phase due to vasoconstriction, which helps to retain heat. Increasing blood flow to the skin would be counterproductive as it would lead to increased heat loss.
  • • Stage W
  • • Stage Y : Increased blood flow to the skin occurs in this phase to facilitate heat loss through the skin, aiding in thermoregulation by cooling the body down.
  • • Stage Y
  • • Option D. Inhibition of chemical thermogenesis
  • • Option D. Inhibition of chemical thermogenesis
  • • Stage W : There is actually an increase in chemical thermogenesis during this stage. Chemical thermogenesis, including actions such as the metabolic effects of shivering and brown fat activation, helps to generate additional heat. Stage Y : As the body temperature stabilizes or exceeds the set point, there might be a natural reduction in chemical thermogenesis as the need to generate heat reduces.
  • • Stage W : There is actually an increase in chemical thermogenesis during this stage. Chemical thermogenesis, including actions such as the metabolic effects of shivering and brown fat activation, helps to generate additional heat.
  • • Stage W
  • • Stage Y : As the body temperature stabilizes or exceeds the set point, there might be a natural reduction in chemical thermogenesis as the need to generate heat reduces.
  • • Stage Y

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TEMPERATURE REGULATION -
  • ➤ TEMPERATURE REGULATION -

questions.text: Sideroblastic anemia can be treated by? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sideroblastic anemia can be treated with Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation, which helps improve heme synthesis and reduce iron accumulation in red blood cell precursors.
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 310
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 310

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes this?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Niacin is another B-vitamin that is essential for various bodily functions. It plays a role in converting nutrients into energy, creating cholesterol and fats, repairing DNA, and acting as an antioxidant. Niacin is important for overall metabolic health. Severe niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which can have serious effects on the skin, digestive system, and nervous system.
  • ➤ Niacin deficiency can be caused by:
  • ➤ Dietary deficiency of tryptophan Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency Carcinoid syndrome Hartnup’s disease
  • ➤ Dietary deficiency of tryptophan
  • ➤ Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome
  • ➤ Hartnup’s disease
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hypothyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypothyroidism causes reversible AV Block that improves with LT4 supplementation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, who had visited multiple plastic surgeons requesting correction of "face deformity," was referred to a Psychiatrist. The patient insists that her face is deformed and needs surgery despite no evidence of deformity in the examination. The patient persists with her demand despite family members’ and doctors' reassurances. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) SSRI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), especially when insight is poor or absent, SSRIs are the drug of choice for management, often in combination with Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Surgery is contraindicated as it does not address the core psychological issue.

questions.text: A medical student accidentally drops a sphygmomanometer, causing mercury spill on the floor. What is the most appropriate method to manage this spill? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Collect using your hand and discard in drain

options.label: B
options.text: Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

options.label: C
options.text: Collect and throw outside in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: Broom it and discard in dustbin

questions.correct_answer: B. Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate method to manage a mercury spill is to collect it using paper/cardboard and place it in a water tube or bucket, then ensure safe and proper disposal. Avoid direct contact, vacuuming, or sweeping the mercury.
  • ➤ The most appropriate method to manage a mercury spill is to collect it using paper/cardboard and place it in a water tube or bucket, then ensure safe and proper disposal.
  • ➤ Avoid direct contact, vacuuming, or sweeping the mercury.

questions.text: Match the following: ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let's match the descriptions to the terms:
  • • A. Depression : "Difficult to diagnose due to the shell of physician’s pride" would suggest that physicians might not show or express their symptoms due to professional pride. So, A matches with 3.
  • • A. Depression :
  • • B. Suicide : "Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles" could be potential risk factors or associated factors. So, B matches with 4.
  • • B. Suicide :
  • • C. Burnout : "State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation" perfectly describes burnout. So, C matches with 2.
  • • C. Burnout :
  • • D. Overthinking : "The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital" does not clearly correlate with overthinking, but given the other matches, this seems the closest fit. So, D matches with 1.
  • • D. Overthinking :
  • • So, the correct matching would be:
  • • A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1.
  • • Reference:
  • • Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 447, 764.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl committed suicide by hanging, after a fight with her boyfriend. On conducting the autopsy, the ligature mark is seen at the lower 1/3rd of the neck and she is seen to have a protruded tongue. One side eye is open and both the pupils are dilated. What is the cause for the open eye? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Cervical sympathetic chain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ PM findings of hanging in the Neck
  • ➤ PM findings of hanging in the Neck
  • ➤ Petechiae-Tardieu spot La facies sympathique Salivary dribbling Ligature mark Tissues under ligature mark are dry, pale, and glistening Thyroid cartilage Hyoid bone fracture
  • ➤ Petechiae-Tardieu spot
  • ➤ La facies sympathique
  • ➤ La facies sympathique
  • ➤ Salivary dribbling
  • ➤ Ligature mark
  • ➤ Tissues under ligature mark are dry, pale, and glistening
  • ➤ Thyroid cartilage
  • ➤ Hyoid bone fracture

questions.text: A paint factory worker working since 20 years complains of joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, headache. He is found to have anemia. Enzyme affected is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ferrochelatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The reference of paint factory worker indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning. Lead affects two enzymes of Heme synthesis pathway:
  • ➤ PBG synthase Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)
  • ➤ PBG synthase
  • ➤ Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)
  • ➤ The defect in any of these enzymes will lead to decrease in haem synthesis resulting in anemia. So, the answer in this case is Ferrochelatase.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 306-307

questions.text: Which clinical test will be positive in a patient who comes with a neglected traumatic dislocation of the hip? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Telescopy test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telescopy test is positive in cases of old, neglected, and traumatic hip dislocations.
  • ➤ Telescopy test is positive in cases of old, neglected, and traumatic hip dislocations.

questions.text: Below is an image of an MRCP scan. Which of the following options is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Choledocholithiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choledocholithiasis is diagnosed primarily through imaging like MRCP, which reveals stones within the common bile duct as distinct circular filling defects. This condition is a significant cause of biliary obstruction and requires prompt diagnosis and management to prevent complications such as severe biliary colic and obstructive jaundice.

questions.text: A child presents with erythematous scaly patches in the perioral region, mucosal ulcers, and impaired epithelial wound healing. What is the likely mineral deficiency associated with this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zinc deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency disorder- Acrodermatitis enteropathica
  • ➤ Zinc deficiency disorder- Acrodermatitis enteropathica

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease presents to you with chest pain and palpitations. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following can be used in the management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs such as amiodarone, procainamide, or sotalol are recommended as first-line treatments according to ACLS guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ β-2 microglobulin is the single most powerful predictor of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma, reflecting the tumor burden and the rate of disease progression.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by parvovirus B19? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Petechial rash

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis, but it is not associated with petechial rash.

questions.text: What is the neoadjuvant therapy used for GIST? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Imatinib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Imatinib is the preferred neoadjuvant therapy for GISTs with KIT or certain PDGFRA mutations to reduce tumor size before surgery. It is not effective for all GISTs, particularly those with specific mutations such as PDGFRA D842V or "wild-type" GISTs.
